title: Cross-site scripting in "Contact customer" form

profile.name: Shopify
profile.about: Shopify is a multi-channel commerce platform that helps people sell online, in-store, and everywhere in between.

vulnerability_information:
Hi, I found HTML Injection Vulnerability while admin contact with customer. In this vulnerability admin is attacker whereas customer is victim. #Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to **Customers** and Click on **Customer Email Address**. 2. New Pop-Up window will become open, In **Customer Message** field type this html code >

HTML INJECTION

3 . Click on **Review Email** Button. HTML will become execute. Checkout the POC Video. Thanks, ## Impact Admin of store can redirect any user to any malicious website, and can perform all possible attacks through this vulnerability.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi,
I found HTML Injection Vulnerability while admin contact with customer.
In this vulnerability admin is attacker whereas customer is victim.

Steps to Reproduce:

  1. Go to Customers and Click on Customer Email Address.
  2. New Pop-Up window will become open, In Customer Message field type this html code

<h1>HTML INJECTION</h1>

3 . Click on Review Email Button.

HTML will become execute.

Checkout the POC Video.

Thanks,

Impact

Admin of store can redirect any user to any malicious website, and can perform all possible attacks through this vulnerability.

activities.message:
Thank you for reporting this issue.

The issue that you describe in your report is listed on our [program page](https://hackerone.com/shopify) under **Known issues or previously reported vulnerabilities**. 

> Any issue where a store administrator is able to insert javascript in the storefront area of their own store, including the checkout pages.

Shopify gives merchants complete control over their store front so they can customize it and make it their own. For this reason, we allow javascript to be included throughout the store by store administrators. This brings risks that we are already aware of, which is why we have excluded the issue from our bounty program and we ask that researchers do not report this kind of issue.

Shopify gives merchants complete control over their store front so they can customize it and make it their own. For this reason, we allow javascript to be included throughout the store by store administrators. This brings risks that we are already aware of, which is why we have excluded the issue from our bounty program and we ask that researchers do not report this kind of issue.

activities.message:
Thank you for reporting this issue.

The issue that you describe in your report is listed on our [program page](https://hackerone.com/shopify) under **Known issues or previously reported vulnerabilities**. 

>  Any issue related to the storefront area being displayed in a <iframe> element in the admin area, for example in the Theme Editor.

Shopify gives merchants complete control over their store front so they can customize it and make it their own. For this reason, we allow javascript to be included throughout the store by store administrators. Wherever possible, we make use of the HTML `sandbox` attribute in order to keep storefront javascript from interfering with the admin area of the site. We are well aware of the issue, which is why we have excluded the issue from our bounty program and we ask that researchers do not report this kind of issue.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for reporting this issue.

The issue that you describe in your report is listed on our program page under Known issues or previously reported vulnerabilities.

Any issue related to the storefront area being displayed in a <iframe> element in the admin area, for example in the Theme Editor.

Shopify gives merchants complete control over their store front so they can customize it and make it their own. For this reason, we allow javascript to be included throughout the store by store administrators. Wherever possible, we make use of the HTML sandbox attribute in order to keep storefront javascript from interfering with the admin area of the site. We are well aware of the issue, which is why we have excluded the issue from our bounty program and we ask that researchers do not report this kind of issue.

Are you serious? Kindly checkout your previous comment.

One of your team member told me that if you will steal some sensitive information / trigger XSS then we will re-open and triage the issue.

activities.message: @protector47 From your screenshot it appeared that script execution was occurring inside an iframe, which is normal. But it appears that may not be the case. We'll have a closer look and get back to you.

activities.message:
Thanks again for your report. We recently deployed a fix for the cross-site scripting issue.

Due to the holiday period, our next round of bounty decisions may be delayed until the second week of January. We'll be in touch with you again by then, if not sooner.

Due to the holiday period, our next round of bounty decisions may be delayed until the second week of January. We'll be in touch with you again by then, if not sooner.
